subject: RE: [junit] assertContains? -> junit development question?
msgSnippet: Hi tek, Glad to hear you adopted JUnit after our book! :) I agree that some more assertMethods would be helpful. Several people have suggested new ones. Maybe
messageBody:
Hi tek,

Glad to hear you adopted JUnit after our book! :) I agree that some more
assertMethods would be helpful. Several people have suggested new ones.
Maybe we should get together and write an assert library as an extension?
Hmmm... I'm not sure I have time, but it seems like a good idea. (Someone
posted a while back about giving better error messages from long String
compares). In the mean time, you can certainly develop your own assert
library for internal use. Here's what I use for contains:

assertTrue(str.indexOf(keywordStr) < 0);

and

assertTrue((Arrays.asList(targetArray)).contains(searchObject));

Cheers,

From: tek1 [mailto:tek1@...]

To: JUnit Mailing List
Subject: [junit] assertContains? -> junit development question?


hello.

i've recently read hightower and lesiecki's book on using ant, junit,
etc.
and have started using junit for my projects. i have noticed that
checking
to see if a string, arrays, and other collections objects contain a
certain
value is often performed.

has there been consideration in the past to add a type of
"assertContains()" methods to the Assert class?

it would create easier-to-read and maintain tests than having to
currently
do containment checks by writing

if(str.indexOf(keywordStr) < 0) {
fail("failed.");
}

or similar checks, and for loops.


the methods could be something like:

assertContains(String containerString, String searchString)
assertContains(String[] containerArray, String searchString)
assertContains(Object[] objectArray, Object searchObject, Class
objClass)


sample usage of the 1st one would be:

containerString = "i love junit and think that everyone should use it.";
searchString = "junit";

assertContains(containerString, searchString); ==> test passes
assertContains(containerString, "weDontNeedTesting"); ==> test fails


thanks and my apologies if this has already been discussed before (i
checked the faq and mailing list for "assert contain" but didn't find
anything...).
